wikipedia_page.main: General Sir Edward Pemberton Leach  (2 April 1847 – 27 April 1913) was a British recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

response: A 9th Division had been formed for service during the Second Boer War, and was commanded by Henry Edward Colvile.Louis Creswicke, South Africa and the Transvaal War, Vol. 6, p. 160 In 1902, a 9th Division was as formed and was commanded by Edward Pemberton Leach, but it was broken-up at some point prior to the start of the war.

response: |Lieutenant-General Edward Pemberton Leach VC CVO CB
* Sir Edward Pemberton Leach (1847–1913), Irish general in the British Army, recipient of the Victoria Cross

Born in Plymouth, the younger daughter of Sir Edward Pemberton Leach, Elsie grew up in a well-connected family that moved across the United Kingdom. From an early age, she was introduced to outdoor pursuits, riding, fishing, and hunting. An interest in birds was sparked off through her friendship with Emma Louisa Turner which led to a meeting with H. F. Witherby in 1930. At that time Witherby was working on the establishment of a marking scheme for British Birds and she took responsibility for the Ringing Scheme in 1937. Her skills at ringing and care in maintaining records were well known and her memory and ability to recall recoveries helped in her work.  She compiled recovery records and produced annual reports from 1938 and went on to produce them until 1951. She retired in 1953 but continued to work on ringing until 1963 when the ringing office shifted to Tring. Her work was recognized by the award of the Bernard Tucker Medal and she was made Member of the Order of the British Empire.

Lieutenant Colonel Sir George Archibald Leach, KCB (25 April 1820 – 18 June 1913) was an English civil servant. He entered the Royal Engineers in 1837 and retired on half-pay in 1861 with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. From 1854 to 1861, he had been in charge of the Irish Survey for the Ordnance Survey. He was appointed an assistant tithe commissioner in 1861, full commissioner in 1877 and then a Land Commissioner from 1882. On the establishment of the Board of Agriculture in 1889, he became its Permanent Secretary, serving until 1892. His uncle was the judge Sir John Leach; his sons included the army officers Sir Edward Pemberton Leach and Harold Pemberton Leach and his daughter married Sir Joseph Savory."Obituary: Lieutenant-Colonel Sir George Leach", The Times (London), 20 June 1913, p. 11. .
